title: Plant Trait Synonym Sources
description: Authoritative sources for botanical terminology and synonyms used in plant trait ontologies

NEWCOMB.name: Newcomb's Wildflower Guide
NEWCOMB.author: Lawrence Newcomb
NEWCOMB.description: Primary source for trait categories and values in the identification key. Uses a 3-digit numerical system combining flower type, plant type, and leaf type.

KEW_GLOSSARY.name: The Kew Plant Glossary: An Illustrated Dictionary of Plant Terms
KEW_GLOSSARY.author: Henk Beentje
KEW_GLOSSARY.description: Comprehensive illustrated glossary with 4144 botanical terms. Based on Flora of Tropical East Africa glossary. Authoritative source from Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.

keyDefinitions.zygomorphic: bilaterally symmetric, with only one plane of symmetry
keyDefinitions.alternate: inserted at different levels of the axis; as distinct from opposite
keyDefinitions.caespitose: growing in tight groups, the bases of the individual plants touching

WIKI_FLORAL_SYMMETRY.name: Wikipedia: Floral symmetry
WIKI_FLORAL_SYMMETRY.description: Article on flower symmetry with scientific terminology. Notes that actinomorphic describes radial symmetry (divisible into 3+ identical sectors), while zygomorphic describes bilateral symmetry.

WIKI_PHYLLOTAXIS.name: Wikipedia: Phyllotaxis
WIKI_PHYLLOTAXIS.description: Article on leaf arrangement patterns with mathematical basis (Fibonacci relationships)

EBSCO_LEAF.name: EBSCO Research Starters: Leaf arrangements
EBSCO_LEAF.author: Magrath, Lawrence K.
EBSCO_LEAF.description: Academic reference article on phyllotaxy. Distinguishes alternate spiral, opposite, and whorled/verticillate arrangements.

PLANT_ONTOLOGY.name: Plant Ontology (OBO Foundry)
PLANT_ONTOLOGY.description: Formal ontology linking plant anatomy, morphology and development to genomics. OBO Foundry compliant for semantic interoperability.

USDA_PLANTS.name: USDA PLANTS Database
USDA_PLANTS.description: U.S. government database with standardized growth habit categories used in official plant species records

PMC_TRY_PUBLICATION.name: TRY – a global database of plant traits (Kattge et al.)
PMC_TRY_PUBLICATION.description: Foundational publication for TRY database trait vocabulary

MOBOT_LATIN.name: Missouri Botanical Garden Latin Dictionary
MOBOT_LATIN.description: Comprehensive online Latin-English botanical dictionary maintained by Missouri Botanical Garden. Provides etymological and definitional information for botanical Latin terms.

incorporationStatus.note: Terms are being added incrementally as they are verified in the MOBOT Latin Dictionary

highTrustSources.note: Curated subset of the most authoritative sources for botanical definitions. These sources are institutional, peer-reviewed, or government-maintained references.

sources.name: Planteome
sources.description: Plant ontology consortium providing reference ontologies for plant biology. Integrates Plant Ontology (PO), Plant Trait Ontology (TO), and other plant-related ontologies.
sources.qualification: Consortium of leading botanical research institutions providing formal ontologies for plant science
World-leading botanical research institution (Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew). Comprehensive peer-reviewed glossary with 4144 terms.
Leading botanical research institution (Missouri Botanical Garden). Comprehensive Latin-English botanical dictionary with etymological information.
Formal ontology from OBO Foundry, part of Planteome consortium. Authoritative for semantic interoperability and genomics applications.
Foundational reference for this project's identification key structure and trait categories.
Peer-reviewed academic reference article (Magrath, 2023) on phyllotaxy.
Peer-reviewed journal article (Global Change Biology, 2011) establishing TRY database trait vocabulary.
U.S. government database with standardized terminology used in official plant species records.

excludedSources.note: The following sources are valuable references but not designated as high trust due to their crowdsourced or general encyclopedia nature

usageGuidelines.preferHighTrust: When multiple sources define a term, prefer high trust sources for primary definitions
usageGuidelines.multipleDefinitions: Include definitions from multiple high trust sources if they provide substantively different perspectives
usageGuidelines.sourceAttribution: Always maintain source attribution for each definition

actinomorphicVsMerosity.note: IMPORTANT: 'Actinomorphic' describes SYMMETRY TYPE (radial, can be divided into equal parts along multiple planes). The merosity terms (dimerous, trimerous, pentamerous, etc.) describe PETAL COUNT. These are independent characteristics - a 5-petaled flower can be actinomorphic (all petals equal) or zygomorphic (petals unequal). Per Kew Plant Glossary: actinomorphic = 'regular, radially symmetric'.

phyllotaxisSpelling.note: Both 'phyllotaxis' and 'phyllotaxy' are accepted spellings for leaf arrangement patterns.

_metadata.citation: Beentje, H.J. (2010). The Kew Plant Glossary. Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.
_metadata.note: Definitions marked [KEW] are verbatim or paraphrased from The Kew Plant Glossary. Page numbers reference the PDF.

mobotLatinStatus.note: Missouri Botanical Garden Latin Dictionary definitions are being added incrementally. Terms verified: actinomorphic

actinomorphic.definition: Radially symmetric, so that a line drawn through the middle of a structure along any plane will produce a mirror image on either side; regular; capable of bisection through two or more planes into similar halves. OPPOSITE: zygomorphic
actinomorphic.commonLanguageDefinition: Having radial symmetry like a wheel or star - can be divided into equal halves in multiple directions. OPPOSITE: zygomorphic (bilateral)

zygomorphic.definition: (of flowers) bilaterally symmetric, divisible into mirror-image halves along only one plane. OPPOSITE: actinomorphic
zygomorphic.commonLanguageDefinition: Having bilateral symmetry like a human face - can be divided into equal halves in only one direction (left and right). OPPOSITE: actinomorphic (radial)

bilateral symmetry.definition: Symmetry in which the two halves of an organ are mirror images of each other along a single plane
bilateral symmetry.commonLanguageDefinition: Symmetry where the two halves are mirror images of each other, like a human face or butterfly

bilaterally symmetrical.definition: Having bilateral symmetry; divisible into equal halves along one plane only

monosymmetric.definition: With a single plane of symmetry; synonym for zygomorphic

dimerous.definition: With flower parts in sets of two

2-merous.definition: The number of parts of a flower being 2, or in 2s (from suffix -merous)

two-parted.definition: Divided into or consisting of two parts

trimerous.definition: With flower parts in sets of three

3-merous.definition: The number of parts of a flower being 3, or in 3s

three-parted.definition: Divided into or consisting of three parts

tetramerous.definition: With flower parts in sets of four

4-merous.definition: The number of parts of a flower being 4, or in 4s

four-parted.definition: Divided into or consisting of four parts

pentamerous.definition: With flower parts in sets of five

5-merous.definition: The number of parts of a flower being 5, or in 5s

five-parted.definition: Divided into or consisting of five parts

hexamerous.definition: With flower parts in sets of six

6-merous.definition: The number of parts of a flower being 6, or in 6s

six-parted.definition: Divided into or consisting of six parts

polymerous.definition: With many parts; having numerous members in each whorl

multimerous.definition: With many parts in each floral whorl

many-parted.definition: Divided into or consisting of many (7+) parts

composite head.definition: A type of inflorescence (capitulum) characteristic of Compositae/Asteraceae where many small florets are densely packed
composite head.commonLanguageDefinition: A flower head made of many tiny flowers packed together (like a sunflower or daisy)

capitulum.definition: A compact cluster of ± sessile flowers; the capitulum may be surrounded by specialised bracts, the involucre
capitulum.commonLanguageDefinition: A compact cluster of flowers attached directly without individual stems, often surrounded by a ring of modified leaves

pseudanthium.definition: A flower-like structure composed of multiple flowers (florets) aggregated together, as in Compositae/Asteraceae
pseudanthium.commonLanguageDefinition: A structure that looks like a single flower but is actually many tiny flowers grouped together (like a daisy or sunflower)

head.commonLanguageDefinition: A short, dense cluster of flowers (flower head)

growth habit.definition: General growth form category used in USDA PLANTS (e.g., tree, shrub, vine, forb/herb, graminoid)

plant growth form.definition: General morphology category of plants as used in trait databases (e.g., TRY)

life form.definition: General morphological and functional category for plants used in trait ecology (e.g., TRY)

habit.definition: General appearance, growth form, or mode of growth of a plant

herb.definition: A plant having the nature of a herb; non-woody, with stems dying back seasonally
herb.commonLanguageDefinition: A non-woody plant whose stems die back each season (like most garden flowers and vegetables)
herb.note: From suffix -aceous: 'herbaceous, having the nature of a herb'

herbaceous.definition: Having the nature of a herb; not woody; with above-ground parts dying back seasonally
herbaceous.commonLanguageDefinition: Non-woody; having soft stems that die back each season (opposite of woody plants like trees and shrubs)

forb.definition: Herbaceous plant less than 2 m tall, excluding grass-like plants, usually annual, usually covered in leaves (no bare stem) [rather vague term, not recommended]

forb/herb.definition: USDA growth habit category for non-woody vascular plants that are not graminoids

herbaceous plant.definition: A plant that has no persistent woody stem above ground

bush.definition: 1. Woody plant intermediate between shrub and tree, 3–7 m high and usually multistemmed [not recommended]; 2. Low and thick shrub, usually without a distinct trunk [not recommended]; 3. Often used in the same sense as shrub [shrub is preferred]

woody shrub.definition: A shrub with persistent woody stems; USDA growth habit category

subshrub.definition: A low-growing shrub, woody only at the base with the upper parts herbaceous and often dying back

fruticose.definition: With the characters of a shrub, shrubby

suffrutescent.definition: Slightly shrubby; woody only at the base

climber.definition: A plant that grows upwards by attaching itself to other structures which it uses as supports; by contrast, a scrambler does not attach itself to its supports
climber.commonLanguageDefinition: A plant that grows upward by attaching itself to other plants, trees, or structures for support (like ivy or morning glory)

liana.definition: A woody climbing or twining plant, especially in tropical forests
liana.commonLanguageDefinition: A woody vine that climbs by wrapping around trees, especially common in tropical forests (like Tarzan's vines)

climbing plant.definition: A plant that climbs using other plants or structures for support
climbing plant.commonLanguageDefinition: A plant that climbs using other plants or structures for support

trailing.definition: Prostrate but not rooting at the nodes; growing along the ground
trailing.commonLanguageDefinition: Lying flat and growing along the ground without putting down roots at the leaf attachment points

scandent.definition: Climbing, usually by means of hooks, tendrils, or twining stems
scandent.commonLanguageDefinition: Climbing by using hooks, coiling tendrils, or wrapping stems around supports

twiner.definition: A climbing plant that twines its stem around a support
twiner.commonLanguageDefinition: A climbing plant that wraps its stem around a support in a spiral pattern (like pole beans)

phyllotaxis.definition: The arrangement of leaves on a stem; leaf arrangement patterns
phyllotaxis.commonLanguageDefinition: The pattern of how leaves are arranged on a stem

phyllotaxy.definition: The arrangement of leaves on a stem (alternate spelling of phyllotaxis)
phyllotaxy.commonLanguageDefinition: The pattern of how leaves are arranged on a stem (alternate spelling)

leaf distribution.definition: The pattern of leaf placement along stems

scale leaves.definition: Reduced, often protective leaves, typically small, dry, and membranous

reduced leaves.definition: Leaves that are smaller than typical for the species, often modified for functions other than photosynthesis

squamate.definition: Covered with or consisting of scales; scale-like

rosette.definition: A cluster of leaves or other organs arranged in a circle, often at the base of a plant
rosette.commonLanguageDefinition: A circular cluster of leaves arranged like the petals of a rose, often at the base of a plant (like a dandelion)

basal rosette.definition: A rosette of leaves at the base of a plant, at or near ground level
basal rosette.commonLanguageDefinition: A circular cluster of leaves at the base of a plant, at or near ground level (like a dandelion or lettuce)

radical leaves.definition: Leaves arising from the root or root crown; basal leaves
radical leaves.commonLanguageDefinition: Leaves that grow directly from the root area at the base of the plant

acaulescent.definition: Without a stem (preferred term for this is acaulous; the ending -escent implies change)
acaulescent.commonLanguageDefinition: Without a visible stem; leaves appear to grow directly from the ground

rosulate.definition: Arranged in a rosette; forming a rosette
rosulate.commonLanguageDefinition: Arranged in a circular cluster like a rosette

alternate.definition: Inserted at different levels of the axis; as distinct from opposite; see also spirally arranged
alternate.commonLanguageDefinition: Leaves arranged one per node at different heights along the stem (not in pairs)

spiral.definition: Arranged in a spiral pattern around the stem; a type of alternate arrangement
spiral.commonLanguageDefinition: Arranged in a spiral pattern winding around the stem

alternate spiral.definition: Leaves arranged singly at nodes in a spiral pattern ascending the stem
alternate spiral.commonLanguageDefinition: Leaves arranged one at a time in a spiral pattern going up the stem

distichous.definition: In two opposite rows, one on each side of the stem
distichous.commonLanguageDefinition: Arranged in two opposite rows, one on each side of the stem (like corn leaves)

scattered.definition: Irregularly arranged; not in any obvious pattern
scattered.commonLanguageDefinition: Irregularly arranged; not in any obvious pattern

opposite.definition: Arising in pairs at the same node, on opposite sides of the stem
opposite.commonLanguageDefinition: Leaves arranged in pairs at the same point on the stem, on opposite sides (like a cross when viewed from above)

whorled.definition: Three or more organs arranged in a circle at one node
whorled.commonLanguageDefinition: Three or more leaves arranged in a ring around the stem at the same point

verticillate.definition: Arranged in a whorl or whorls; whorled
verticillate.commonLanguageDefinition: Arranged in a ring or rings around the stem

decussate.definition: Used of opposite organs (e.g. leaves), when alternate pairs are at right angles to each other
decussate.commonLanguageDefinition: Leaves in pairs that alternate at 90-degree angles, forming an X pattern when viewed from above

verticil.definition: A whorl; a ring of similar parts arranged around an axis
verticil.commonLanguageDefinition: A ring of similar parts (like leaves) arranged around the stem

generalBotanicalTerms.note: Foundational botanical terms used across multiple trait definitions

node.definition: The part of a stem where one or more leaves, branches, or aerial roots are attached
node.commonLanguageDefinition: The point on a plant stem where leaves attach (like a joint on your finger)

axis.definition: The main or central line of development of a plant or organ; the main stem
axis.commonLanguageDefinition: The main stem or central line of a plant

whorl.definition: An arrangement of three or more similar organs (such as leaves, flowers, or floral parts) radiating from a single node
whorl.commonLanguageDefinition: Three or more leaves (or flowers) arranged in a ring around the stem at the same point

organ.definition: A distinct and visibly differentiated part of a plant, such as a root, stem, leaf, or floral part
organ.commonLanguageDefinition: A distinct part of a plant, such as a root, stem, leaf, or flower part

inflorescence.definition: The arrangement of flowers on a plant; the flowering part of a plant
inflorescence.commonLanguageDefinition: The flowering part of a plant; how the flowers are arranged on the stem

bract.definition: A modified, often reduced, leaf associated with a flower or inflorescence
bract.commonLanguageDefinition: A modified leaf near a flower, often smaller or different-colored than regular leaves

involucre.definition: A whorl or rosette of bracts surrounding or subtending a flower, flower cluster, or fruit
involucre.commonLanguageDefinition: A ring of modified leaves (bracts) surrounding a flower or flower cluster

floret.definition: A small flower, especially one of the small individual flowers in a dense inflorescence such as a capitulum
floret.commonLanguageDefinition: A small individual flower, especially one of many packed together in a flower head

sessile.definition: Without a stalk; attached directly by the base
sessile.commonLanguageDefinition: Attached directly without a stem (like a button sewn flat onto fabric)

root.definition: The descending axis of a plant, normally underground, which anchors the plant and absorbs water and nutrients
root.commonLanguageDefinition: The underground part of a plant that anchors it and absorbs water and nutrients from the soil

tendril.definition: A slender, coiling or twining organ used for climbing, modified from a stem, leaf, or leaflet
tendril.commonLanguageDefinition: A thin, coiling structure that plants use to climb and attach to supports (like a curly phone cord)

hook.definition: A curved or bent structure used for attachment or climbing
hook.commonLanguageDefinition: A curved structure that helps plants attach to things or climb

twining.definition: Winding spirally around a support; the growth habit of climbing by spiral growth
twining.commonLanguageDefinition: Winding around a support in a spiral pattern (like a vine wrapping around a pole)

rooting.definition: Producing roots, especially adventitious roots from stems or nodes
rooting.commonLanguageDefinition: Producing roots, especially from stems or the points where leaves attach

flower parts.definition: The constituent organs of a flower, including sepals, petals, stamens, and carpels
flower parts.commonLanguageDefinition: The different parts that make up a flower, including petals and reproductive structures

petal.definition: One of the segments of the corolla, usually colored and conspicuous
petal.commonLanguageDefinition: One of the colored, often showy parts of a flower (the parts we usually think of as 'the flower')

support.definition: A structure (such as another plant, tree, or trellis) that a climbing plant uses to grow upward
support.commonLanguageDefinition: Something a climbing plant uses to grow upward, like another plant, tree, fence, or trellis

cluster.definition: A group of similar organs (such as flowers or fruits) growing closely together
cluster.commonLanguageDefinition: A group of similar parts (like flowers or fruits) growing close together
